prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NB1H43
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted 158um [CII] emission and underlying continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). We fit a greybody to these data points to predict the rest-frame 158um continuum flux and total far-IR luminosity. We assume the spatially integrated [CII] flux measured with the Herschel/SPIRE FTS for this source (George et al. 2013). We then very conservatively assume that the [CII] emission is resolved over 15 beams (same assumption for the continuum), and require to reach a signal-to-noise-ratio (S/N) of 10 per beam over the line FWHM (i.e., S/N>4.5 over a velocity bin of 1/5 the FWHM), as sufficient to determine the velocity structure in channel maps across the line. Regardless of S/N, we set the minimum on source time to 7 minutes to attain a minimal level of u-v coverage.
- Imaging: Based on the measured and estimated [CII] fluxes and our existing high-resolution lens models (best-fit u-v plane models to lower resolution ALMA cycle-0 or SMA 880um continuum maps), we have run simalma to confirm that the sources are detectable and that all expected structure can be recovered with the requested configurations (see Fig. 5 in the proposal for 4 examples). All sources fit within the central 1/3 of the primary beam (see Fig. 2 in the proposal for 8 examples). We here assume the C34-4 configuration, but observations in C34-5 would be fully acceptable as well.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. Given the broad lines, no scientific goals are compromised by the binning.
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment
- Bandpass: Our targets are galaxies and thus have broad, but not extremely broad lines. The lines are at least as strong as the underlying continuum. As such, the standard bandpass calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). We however emphasize that no other existing or planned facility would be capable of these observations, given the high observing frequencies (354-710GHz) and high spatial resolution (~0.15"). Given the lengths of the individual science goals, it will be possible to schedule this project highly flexibly. As such, no special constraints exist for this program.

- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). - Imaging: Based on the measured and estimated [CII] fluxes and our existing high-resolution lens models (best-fit u-v plane models to lower resolution ALMA cycle-0 or SMA 880um continuum maps), we have run simalma to confirm that the sources are detectable and that all expected structure can be recovered with the requested configurations (see Fig. 5 in the proposal for 4 examples). All sources fit within the central 1/3 of the primary beam (see Fig. 2 in the proposal for 8 examples). We here assume the C34-4 configuration, but observations in C34-5 would be fully acceptable as well.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. - Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted 158um [CII] emission and underlying continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). We fit a greybody to these data points to predict the rest-frame 158um continuum flux and total far-IR luminosity. We assume the spatially integrated [CII] flux measured with the Herschel/SPIRE FTS for this source (George et al. in prep.). We then conservatively assume that the [CII] emission is resolved over 10 beams (same assumption for the continuum), and require to reach a signal-to-noise-ratio (S/N) of 10 per beam over the line FWHM (i.e., S/N>4.5 over a velocity bin of 1/5 the FWHM), as sufficient to determine the velocity structure in channel maps across the line. All sources fit within the central 1/3 of the primary beam (see Fig. 2 in the proposal for 8 examples). We here assume the C34-4 configuration, but observations in C34-5 would be fully acceptable as well.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G09H97
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted 158um [CII] emission and underlying continuum. Cover 163um OH line in LSB. OH line slightly offset from center to fit LSB.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). We fit a greybody to these data points to predict the rest-frame 158um continuum flux and total far-IR luminosity. All sources have CO 1-0, 2-1, 3-2 and/or 4-3 detections as well as higher-J CO lines (minimum 2-3 lines per source). We determine the CO 1-0 luminosity using standard relations (e.g., Carilli & Walter 2013, ARA&A, 51, 105). We then use the CO/FIR vs. [CII]/FIR relation (Stacey et al. 2010) to predict the [CII] luminosity, and thus, flux (the same line width as for CO is assumed). We then very conservatively assume that the [CII] emission is resolved over 15 beams (same assumption for the continuum), and require to reach a signal-to-noise-ratio (S/N) of 10 per beam over the line FWHM (i.e., S/N>4.5 over a velocity bin of 1/5 the FWHM), as sufficient to determine the velocity structure in channel maps across the line. Regardless of S/N, we set the minimum on source time to 7 minutes to attain a minimal level of u-v coverage.
- Imaging: Based on the measured and estimated [CII] fluxes and our existing high-resolution lens models (best-fit u-v plane models to lower resolution ALMA cycle-0 or SMA 880um continuum maps), we have run simalma to confirm that the sources are detectable and that all expected structure can be recovered with the requested configurations (see Fig. 5 in the proposal for 4 examples). All sources fit within the central 1/3 of the primary beam (see Fig. 2 in the proposal for 8 examples). We here assume the C34-6 configuration, but observations in C34-5 would be acceptable as well.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. The 163um OH emission line is targeted in one baseband in the LSB (line covered as well as possible within the tuning restrictions). 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. Given the broad lines, no scientific goals are compromised by the binning.
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment
- Bandpass: Our targets are galaxies and thus have broad, but not extremely broad lines. The lines are at least as strong as the underlying continuum. As such, the standard bandpass calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). We however emphasize that no other existing or planned facility would be capable of these observations, given the high observing frequencies (354-710GHz) and high spatial resolution (~0.15"). Given the lengths of the individual science goals, it will be possible to schedule this project highly flexibly. As such, no special constraints exist for this program.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID81
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted 158um [CII] emission and underlying continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). We fit a greybody to these data points to predict the rest-frame 158um continuum flux and total far-IR luminosity. We assume the spatially integrated [CII] flux measured with the Herschel/SPIRE FTS for this source (Valtchanov et al. 2011). We then very conservatively assume that the [CII] emission is resolved over 50 beams (same assumption for the continuum; this is the far most extended source in the sample), and require to reach a signal-to-noise-ratio (S/N) of 10 per beam over the line FWHM (i.e., S/N>4.5 over a velocity bin of 1/5 the FWHM), as sufficient to determine the velocity structure in channel maps across the line. Regardless of S/N, we set the minimum on source time to 7 minutes to attain a minimal level of u-v coverage.
- Imaging: Based on the measured and estimated [CII] fluxes and our existing high-resolution lens models (best-fit u-v plane models to lower resolution ALMA cycle-0 or SMA 880um continuum maps), we have run simalma to confirm that the sources are detectable and that all expected structure can be recovered with the requested configurations (see Fig. 5 in the proposal for 4 examples). All sources fit within the central 1/3 of the primary beam (see Fig. 2 in the proposal for 8 examples). We here assume the C34-5 configuration, but observations in C34-6 would be acceptable as well.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. Given the broad lines, no scientific goals are compromised by the binning.
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment
- Bandpass: Our targets are galaxies and thus have broad, but not extremely broad lines. The lines are at least as strong as the underlying continuum. As such, the standard bandpass calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). We however emphasize that no other existing or planned facility would be capable of these observations, given the high observing frequencies (354-710GHz) and high spatial resolution (~0.15"). Given the lengths of the individual science goals, it will be possible to schedule this project highly flexibly. As such, no special constraints exist for this program.

- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. The 163um OH emission line is targeted in one baseband in the LSB (line covered as well as possible within the tuning restrictions). 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. Given the broad lines, no scientific goals are compromised by the binning.
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID141
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted 158um [CII] emission and underlying continuum. Cover 163um OH line in LSB (offset from baseband center).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). We fit a greybody to these data points to predict the rest-frame 158um continuum flux and total far-IR luminosity. We assume the spatially integrated [CII] flux measured with APEX for this source (Cox et al. 2011). We then very conservatively assume that the [CII] emission is resolved over 20 beams (same assumption for the continuum; this is one of the more extended source in the sample), and require to reach a signal-to-noise-ratio (S/N) of 10 per beam over the line FWHM (i.e., S/N>4.5 over a velocity bin of 1/5 the FWHM), as sufficient to determine the velocity structure in channel maps across the line. Regardless of S/N, we set the minimum on source time to 7 minutes to attain a minimal level of u-v coverage.
- Imaging: Based on the measured and estimated [CII] fluxes and our existing high-resolution lens models (best-fit u-v plane models to lower resolution ALMA cycle-0 or SMA 880um continuum maps), we have run simalma to confirm that the sources are detectable and that all expected structure can be recovered with the requested configurations (see Fig. 5 in the proposal for 4 examples). All sources fit within the central 1/3 of the primary beam (see Fig. 2 in the proposal for 8 examples). We here assume the C34-7 configuration, but observations in C34-6 would be acceptable as well if necessary.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. The 163um OH emission line is targeted in one baseband in the LSB (line covered as well as possible within the tuning restrictions). 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. Given the broad lines, no scientific goals are compromised by the binning.
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment
- Bandpass: Our targets are galaxies and thus have broad, but not extremely broad lines. The lines are at least as strong as the underlying continuum. As such, the standard bandpass calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). We however emphasize that no other existing or planned facility would be capable of these observations, given the high observing frequencies (354-710GHz) and high spatial resolution (~0.15"). Given the lengths of the individual science goals, it will be possible to schedule this project highly flexibly. As such, no special constraints exist for this program.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HELMS59
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted 158um [CII] emission and underlying continuum. Cover 163um OH line in LSB OH offset from center to fit in LSB

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). We fit a greybody to these data points to predict the rest-frame 158um continuum flux and total far-IR luminosity. All sources have CO 1-0, 2-1, 3-2 and/or 4-3 detections as well as higher-J CO lines (minimum 2-3 lines per source). We determine the CO 1-0 luminosity using standard relations (e.g., Carilli & Walter 2013, ARA&A, 51, 105). We then use the CO/FIR vs. [CII]/FIR relation (Stacey et al. 2010) to predict the [CII] luminosity, and thus, flux (the same line width as for CO is assumed). We then very conservatively assume that the [CII] emission is resolved over 15 beams (same assumption for the continuum), and require to reach a signal-to-noise-ratio (S/N) of 10 per beam over the line FWHM (i.e., S/N>4.5 over a velocity bin of 1/5 the FWHM), as sufficient to determine the velocity structure in channel maps across the line. Regardless of S/N, we set the minimum on source time to 7 minutes to attain a minimal level of u-v coverage.

- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. We have overlapped the "cont1" band with another baseband by ~500MHz to avoid the worst region of the atmosphere The 163um OH emission line is targeted in one baseband in the LSB (line covered as well as possible within the tuning restrictions). 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. Given the broad lines, no scientific goals are compromised by the binning.
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment
- Bandpass: Our targets are galaxies and thus have broad, but not extremely broad lines. The lines are at least as strong as the underlying continuum. As such, the standard bandpass calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). We however emphasize that no other existing or planned facility would be capable of these observations, given the high observing frequencies (354-710GHz) and high spatial resolution (~0.15"). Given the lengths of the individual science goals, it will be possible to schedule this project highly flexibly. As such, no special constraints exist for this program.

- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment
- Bandpass: Our targets are galaxies and thus have broad, but not extremely broad lines. The lines are at least as strong as the underlying continuum. As such, the standard bandpass calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). We however emphasize that no other existing or planned facility would be capable of these observations, given the high observing frequencies (354-710GHz) and high spatial resolution (~0.15"). Given the lengths of the individual science goals, it will be possible to schedule this project highly flexibly. As such, no special constraints exist for this program.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HELMS10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted 158um [CII] emission and underlying continuum. Cover 163um OH line in LSB (slightly offset from baseband center).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: We here target redshifted 158um [CII] emission and the underlying continuum. All sources have measurements at 250, 350, and 500um, and either 880um or 1.3mm (more data exists for part of the sample). We fit a greybody to these data points to predict the rest-frame 158um continuum flux and total far-IR luminosity. All sources have CO 1-0, 2-1, 3-2 and/or 4-3 detections as well as higher-J CO lines (minimum 2-3 lines per source). We determine the CO 1-0 luminosity using standard relations (e.g., Carilli & Walter 2013, ARA&A, 51, 105). We then use the CO/FIR vs. [CII]/FIR relation (Stacey et al. 2010) to predict the [CII] luminosity, and thus, flux (the same line width as for CO is assumed). We then very conservatively assume that the [CII] emission is resolved over 15 beams (same assumption for the continuum), and require to reach a signal-to-noise-ratio (S/N) of 10 per beam over the line FWHM (i.e., S/N>4.5 over a velocity bin of 1/5 the FWHM), as sufficient to determine the velocity structure in channel maps across the line. Regardless of S/N, we set the minimum on source time to 7 minutes to attain a minimal level of u-v coverage.
- Imaging: Based on the measured and estimated [CII] fluxes and our existing high-resolution lens models (best-fit u-v plane models to lower resolution ALMA cycle-0 or SMA 880um continuum maps), we have run simalma to confirm that the sources are detectable and that all expected structure can be recovered with the requested configurations (see Fig. 5 in the proposal for 4 examples). All sources fit within the central 1/3 of the primary beam (see Fig. 2 in the proposal for 8 examples). We here assume the C34-7 configuration, but observations in C34-6 would be acceptable as well if necessary.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The [CII] line is centered in one baseband, with other basebands covering the continuum emission. The 163um OH emission line is targeted in one baseband in the LSB (line covered as well as possible within the tuning restrictions). 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. Given the broad lines, no scientific goals are compromised by the binning.
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this broad line/continuum imaging experiment
- Bandpass: Our targets are galaxies and thus have broad, but not extremely broad lines. The lines are at least as strong as the underlying continuum. As such, the standard bandpass calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: Data rates are below the expected average of 6MB/s.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes: On source times are 7-16 minutes per target (i.e., similar to many approved studies in cycles 0 and 1), which naturally results in comparatively high overheads per science goal when using the standard calibration scheme (as appropriate). We however emphasize that no other existing or planned facility would be capable of these observations, given the high observing frequencies (354-710GHz) and high spatial resolution (~0.15"). Given the lengths of the individual science goals, it will be possible to schedule this project highly flexibly. As such, no special constraints exist for this program.

The 163um OH emission line is targeted in one baseband in the LSB (line covered as well as possible within the tuning restrictions). 4x spectral binning is applied to maintain standard data rates. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) at high redshift are thought to be dominantly highly dissipative mergers of gas-rich galaxies that represent extreme, short-lived starbursts. This picture is supported by studies of gas dynamics, but unfortunately, the resolution of these past studies remained limited to 3-4 kpc even for the best handful of cases (with only a single exception), which is barely adequate to resolve the galaxies. Using the advanced capabilities of ALMA in cycle-2 (in particular band 8 and the longest baselines) and the magnifying effect provided by gravitational lensing, we here propose to study the [CII] gas dynamics in a large, carefully-selected sample of 14 Herschel-selected DSFGs covering the peak epoch of galaxy formation down to 100-500pc resolution. Based on uv plane lens modeling and dynamical models, we will investigate the occurence rate of major mergers vs. disks in our sample, measure dynamical masses, and constrain the physical properties of individual gas clumps down to physical scales that will only become accessible with full ALMA in unlensed galaxies at these distances. This comprehensive investigation thus will remain unrivaled for years to come.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00539S: Lensing Properties of the Brightest Herschel-Selected Submillimeter Galaxies (PI: Riechers)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
